narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Everyone should know at least a little about those bizarre German authors, with their wild hair and walrus mustaches. You read some works by the best modernist authors-- Rilke, Benjamin, Brecht, Kafka. Sussman is lovely, and effusively enthusiastic about the stuff he teaches--though there are times when he pontificates and people kind of lose track of what's going on.

Very good class with a great professor. Prof. Sussman has a very flexible and cross-discipline mind. We mad valuable connections among the works we've read. In class, we continuously generate engaging ideas.Great reading material, especially Kafka, Rilke, Benjamin, Brecht and Bernhard.

A recommendation for or against this class is essentially a recommendation for or against Henry Sussman, who with some accuracy dubbed himself a âmale hystericâ and an âaging hippieâ during our class sessions. Itâs a survey of German-language Modernist literature conducted in translation. As Sussman is not one to tread the beaten path, the texts we read were not necessarily the most obvious ones; Kafka, Freud, Rilke were all represented by works conventionally considered âlesser,â and we read three works from beyond the historical period most often associated with Modernism. Sussman is an able seminar leader, a formidable intellect, a kind and shrewd critic of individual work, and a frequent generator of quotable âgems.â I thoroughly enjoyed his company for the semester; some might not. No harm in shopping.
A very enjoyable course. Highly recommended.
I would definitely recommend German Modernism to anyone interested in literature of the time period. We read a lot of wonderful works, and Professor Sussman is amazing.
